transcript.content: On XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant and back Karl Pilkington.
He's rarin' to go. That's nice when you have a bit of time off, innit?
Yeah, how long have you had off now then, Karl?

About three weeks, yeah. Uhm, we can't do that because we're sort of self-employed and we'd be lettin' people down but it's different when you're- you know, you get paid anyway whether you turn up or not but good to have you back. Good to have you--
I'm not a- I'm never off ill.
That I've been off ill at XFM.
Well, no, just- just shoot off for two weeks and then you're off--
No, I just wish I was the kind of person who could let down an audience--

Well, no, we spoke to you, you weren't that bad- a cold- you don't go in for a cold. Uh, we were discussing this last night in the pub and, uh, you know, you don't go in for a cold. Uhm, okay then, moving on, what have we got, then? We've got some great songs, I brought--
In The Smiths, I brought in Buzzcocks, I brought in Neil Young, I know Steve's got some hip hop.
Some great Elvis Costello. It's gonna be great. Karl come on, (Taps Desk) concentrate. You've been away three weeks.
It just annoys me- no, stop sayin' that--
Why?... W- what are you gonna do? Go home ill? (Mocking Voice) "Ohh. Ooh, he's annoyed me." "Oh, has he?" "Yeah--"
(Mocking Voice) "I got a bit of a headache!"
(Mocking Voice) "I put on wet jeans, I'm a little bit annoyed."
(Mocking Voice) "Can I have some time off but still get paid?" "Yes, of course you can, Karl."
Steve, right, he called me up, winding me up about this--
And, right, I'm- I'm nearly- I'm thirty, right- I'm thirty now--
I can only remember being off two times.
Oh, his memory's goin' as well. You'll have some time off.
And both of them were when I- when I was at school. One- one--
(Laughing Slightly) Why did you have to have off cuz it was windy?
But, to be honest, Karl, that lasted for seven years--
Wait, wait, wait, why did you have time off cuz it was windy?
Were you windy or was it windy outside?
No, it was a really- it was like when--
Your auntie wasn't out the window, was she?
When- when the winds were bad in the seventies and me mam said, "Oooh--"
What'd you- whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoahhh. I remember space hoppers and flares--
I don't remember the winds being bad in the seventies.
Well me- me mam just said, uhh, "You might get blown into the road so don't go in."
She had so much faith in you, didn't she... as a human being?
Is that why she got fired from the pie shop?
"I'm not coming in today, I might get blown into the road."
The funny thing was, right, Steve, they had this- this thing goin' at school - cuz a lot of kids used to wag it back then, right--
Wag it - sort of, not go in.
And, ehm, they, sort of, tried to make it interesting for you by giving you a--
Certificate if you did a full week.
A reward for the rest of your life--
With achievement. That sort of- that sort of carrot.
And also, like, let you got home at three o'clock on a Friday--
If you'd done a- like, a full week and that, right.
So it was a- it was lovely weather all week, then it just, sort of, changed on a Friday--
And I got off and it was all windy and me mam said--
It's always windy on Fridays and Sundays, innit?
Uhh, "Don't- don't, you know- if you don't want, don't go in cuz you might get blown into the road and that."
So I said, "All right then, I'll stay off." And, uhhhm--
Sorry, why didn't she... told you held on- hold on to a fence or--
Walk ya there. What's this "don't go out, you might get blown--"
I love this "getting blown into the road". Is that based on your cats that kept gettin' blown into the road?
Well... So, I got to- got to school on Monday, right, and the teacher said, "Right--"
"Today, uh, to punish you - you were the only one who wrecked the whole week, right- everyone else came in, you didn't, so everyone else is going home at three o'clock today... but you're not."
Brilliant. Serves you right and, uh- and--
I wasn't bothered though, it was great cuz I said, "Well, you'll have to stay with me, won't ya?"
And it's great. So, all I did for half an hour was doodle and stuff. It was great- little afternoon.
And that- that was ages ago. That was, like, when I was about... eight. And that's one of the times I was off ill.
But that wasn't even ill, that was wind.
Yeah. Yeah, it's a bit different when you're--

In the adult world though, Karl. You can't just not turn up because you've got a bit of a cold or you're a bit fed up... I mean, we had an appointment four o'clock Thursday, wasn't it, and he had to call up, he said, "Aw, cancel it", I went on, "meeting went a little bit late."
(Tsk Sound) (Banging the Desk on each Word) Time management. Get things done. If it was important, you'd get it done. Play a record, Karl.
Elvis Costello, "Alison". What a great track that is.
Beautiful. Well, Karl, we better tell 'em all the new great features we've come up with... in the time... you were off.
Right, well, we'll, uhh- we've got the film thing still goin'.
That's where you take a lead role or a m- or a- a major role in a- in a Hollywood blockbuster which we then give away on VHS - worth 6.99.
And, uhh, something new we're trying out cuz "Rockbusters"--
Is, uhh- is gone for a bit.
Ooooh, this sounds intrigueing, where'd you get the idea from?
What's- what's the basic, uh, format of this?
Right, what I- what I've done is: I've, uhh--
Take- take, like, a- a popular saying from the show...
A popular saying, something that crops up quite a lot in the show.
Uhhhm, first thing that spring- sort of, sprang to mind was, uh, "There's this hairy Chinese kid."
But more- more commonly it would be something like "Karl, you're an idiot"--
Yeah, "Play a record you ignorant fool"--
"Ooh, what do you mean? You let us down again. You should have been here."--
(Mocking Tone) "Oh, you've got a headache, have you Karl? You better have a lie down."
Yeah. Typical phrases like that, yeah. Yeah.
Right. And, uhm, what I've done, I've got a load of different songs and took words--
From the different songs and then joined them together--
To make "There's this hairy Chinese kid" and then people have to email in and say what the five songs were.
It sounds like the most complicated game ever.... I'm looking forward to it. Are you- have you heard any of this, Rick, cuz I've not heard this at all--
Well, all it is, it'll- it'll go, like, (Disjointed Tones) "Hairy. Chi. Nese. Kid." and that's- it's from, sort of, four different songs--
And you've got to identify the songs.
How many songs in this, Karl? You o--
(Laughing Slightly) And, uh, what are the prizes for that? Are these the prizes?
All right, well let me tell you what they are. They're not too bad, actually. We've got, uhm, "Live Forever" which I assume is a CD that ties in with this new film--
Think of that... A well-known phrase from the show and it's "Hairy Chinese kid"!
What other- where would you hear that?!
There is no other radio show in the world--
In life. I... this is... Go on.
If you've just tuned in, I mean, what do you think?
What do you think if you've just tuned in? And go, (Slight Manc Accent) "Well-known phrase from show: "Hairy Chinese kid."
They'll be playing that in charades this Christmas.

Ah, so, yeah, this is, uh, a CD that ties into this new film "Live Forever" which is all- is all  about, uh, Britpop and so there's stuff on there from Oasis, Blur, Pulp, etc. Uh, we've also got, uh, another "Red Dwarf" DVD. Uhh, "Marion and Geoff", the first series of that, excellent--

It's on VHS, sadly but, uh, nevermind. And, uhmmm- and also "The Very Best of Led Zepplin", a two CD set there with all the classics on. So that's not bad prizes actually, Karl. You've done yourself proud.

That is, uh- we've upped it- we've upped it, we're getting serious now. We're playing in the, you know- the bigger league. We've upped the stakes, we want "Heat" magazine not to, you know, lose touch with us just because "Rockbusters" is gone.
I think they're still behind us. We've got to show the worried--
So, we've got- we've got, uhh- we've got "Film..."- you appear in a film--
We've got (Laughing Slightly) "Crosswords." How is that to do with a crossword?
Because I've got words and, sort of, crossed them.
Right. You haven't really crossed them.
But, uh, good. So, "Words". We're playing a game called, "Words".
"Word Song". Hello, and welcome to "Word Song".
And, uhh- and obviously I imagine there'll be some more great music.
But we've got a new feature, haven't we?
Are we doing... uhm, within the monkey news, the new feature?
I'm excited. You know "Monkey News" is my favorite feature so what have you added to it?
Right, well, uhhh, there's been loads of stuff going on in the past few weeks, all right? Ehhh, but for the times when I struggle, when- when, sort of, monkeys have had a quiet week...
And- and there isn't that much news goin' on, right--
Come up with this thing... I, sort of, speak to an expert, I've- I've spoke to him already, right...
You spoke- you spoke to an expert?
And I ask him a question.
Right? The feature... it's got a good name, you know that's the way I work.
And what I do, I ask them a question about, you know, oooh, how much does it cost to, you know, keep one... how much does it cost to, you know, feed one for a week.
All this sort of stuff. So, I- I give out, like, a monkey story and if that isn't enough for people, they'll also learn something else at the end of it.
It sounds fascinating, can I say right now.
That's just some of the things that we've come up with. Play a record, Karl.
Please still continue to listen though.
Richard Ashcroft - Buy It In Bottles
Richard Ashcroft, "Buy It In Bottles" on XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington.
Karl, I need the phone number of your girlfriend.
Let me explain why. I was lucky enough, once again, to be on your quiz team this week. Uhm, uh, Ricky--
Still to beat me- he's still to beat me with his team yet.

We, uh- the s- the gang here and some friends, we, uh, sometimes go down to a pub quiz in the local area and, uhm, it was very nice of Karl to be invited on his team. Uh, twice now I've been on that team. Ricky's always on another team. And, uhm, I- (Sighs) what can I say, Karl, I- I- do you mind me saying this now because I've- I've- I've analyzed the team and it's your- very much your team and, uh, you've put the team together, you've recruited some excellent personnel, your girlfriend's, uh, very, very good on the team--

As is one of her, uh, work colleagues and, uh, you normally bring in, you know someone like myself. I like to think I'm providing a certain something with the entertainment section, I seem to remember last time, I answered at least six or seven questions that other people hadn't got. So, I- I felt I provided something there. Ehm, Karl, I- I- rather like John Harvey-Jones who used to be called in to, sort of, troubleshoot companies I see why you are not winning ever. And it's a rather pricey, uhh, contest, isn't it? It costs a tenner to enter per person--
And unless you get in the top three, you're not- you're not gonna get to see your money back. So, uhm--
I think you're gonna maybe need to step down--
From the team... because Karl, I'm not sure--
You- you consider yourself a, kind of, player/manager but frankly I'm not sure you're providing enough.

See this is- this is funny because... as bad as I imagine you are, I don't think Steve would make it into my team so he's gettin' a bit cocky here. I wanna know what your opinion of him- cuz he's told me he's great on it.
Well... you're bang out of order, first of all.
Did you have a good night when you were with us?
Um, I tell you what, I wish I'd- I wish I hadn't lost a tenner everytime I've come down.
Your point out there about the football analogy--
When did he score a goal?
He doesn't, he tells the others how to do it.
Right? That's- that's my role in there--
He doesn't take up one of the eleven though, does he?
It's not like you can only field ten--
"We've only got 10 again." (Ferguson Impression) "Alright, I want to be in the eleven."
Yeah. Yeah. Exactly. He's stopped running around in midfield--
Yeah, shoutin', (Ferguson Impression) "Aww, what have I told ya?"
And there's a limit of five players. We should explain that. That's the point.
Yeah. There's only five pe- players on the team.
But, it- it was pretty tricky on Tuesday, though, wannit? It was one of the tougher--
T- t- tell everyone the one question you got right.
Well, tell us the answer, the two words you had to say to get the answer.
That was what you provided - Dannii Minogue.
Well, no- not- not- really because--
Because- because there was at least two of us who also knew the answer.
We- we gave him- we gave him the--
No, exactly. We gave it to Karl. We- massage his ego. But, uhm...
I- I- do you know what? I'm a little- I feel a little bit bad, now cuz I just saw- he had a crushed face on him--
Can- can I just tell you right now--

Can I just tell you right now, I think the problem is this: I think there's that precious fifth position that is not being filled - at the moment, I think - consistently enough by a decent player. Right, you've got a solid team. I'm thinking if you want to remain on the team you are gonna have to pull your finger out and find a fifth member that is gonna provide- and I'll tell you where the weaknesses are, I can tell you right now, mate. The weaknesses are natural history and science--
Something which Ricky Gervais is scoring on week-in and week-out on his team.
There is- there is a few science--
Now, if he was available for a transfer, we could be fine--
But we've got to find someone to fill in that space otherwise I'm either gonna quit or you're gonna have to step down because I don't think I can be on a team where--
Where he- dare he loses ten pounds--
Where there are obvious deficiencies- are visible deficiencies on your team.
Um, and you know, the ten pounds.
That's ten pounds - I'm not made of money.
I've- I've seen him depressed for two hours when he lost twenty pounds at a casino after five hours playing.
Don't bring it back. Don't bring- don't bring that back.
Don't bring up that again, that story.
He doesn't like wastin' money, Karl. You know that.
What do you think? What do you think? What's the solution? You've got to be- (Slapping His Palm) we've got to think proactively, now. We have got to sort this out.
See, there's always other things going on in me mind when I'm at that pub quiz.
For me, it's just a little bit of fun--
It's a night out, do you know what I mean?
Bit of a get together, we have a chat beforehand--
We have a bit of fun.
But there's other things on me mind.
Karl, I could do that here, I don't have to lose a tenner.
No, wait. Wait, what were you thinking during the quiz, there when the questions were comin' out? What were you thinking of?
Well, what it was, right... just before the quiz started, I had to go the the toilet, right, because the rule is, right -  people who don't go to it - once it starts, phones off--
Oh yeah, you can't leave the room, yeah.
No more toilet. They take it dead serious, don't they, right?
So, I went to the toilet.... Now, I'm not bein' out of order here, it just got me thinking, right.
I went to the toilet... there's a gay fella in there. All right?
There was a gay fella in there?
How did you know? How did you know?
Just typical, you know... everything about it. Right--
Butt- butt plugs, ammonitrate- could I just say that... these views do not reflect the views of the management of XFM or me and Steve. Go on. Karl.
Or most of the people of this country. On you go.
Go on- go on, Karl. What's your problem?
Yeah, but this is what I'm worried about, really- but this is why I only got Danni Minogue right.
All right? Cuz this was floatin' around me mind. Went to the toilet--
She's a big gay icon, isn't she?
Now... go into the toilet.. they have- they have, like, men's cubicle and they have women's cubicle...
Now without sounding out of order... is it wrong for me to think...
Gay men should have their own little cubicle?
They should have their own- well not cubicle, you mean an actual toilet, I suppose.
Yeah. When I was at the urinal...
Normally, you know, there's a fella there and you go, "All right?", and there's no pressure.
But I couldn't- I couldn't go. I was thinking, "Should I wait? If I go into the toilet, it'll look obvious--"
I had loads of pressure and this was going on--
But what were you worried about?
I am so sorry, viewers. I am so sorry.
Well, it's like- right, listen, when I was a kid, right--
And it's all right for you to go into women's toilets when you're a kid, it's like, "Oooh, it's a bit cute."
Right? As long as you're not, like, over fifteen or something, right.
But, when I was a kid I went into the toilet and women, when they use their little cubicles, they don't shut the door. Some of 'em just sit down on the- on the toilet.
No, seriously that's probably one of the first times I saw, like, a woman.
That, right, and me Auntie Nora when she was stayin' over.
(Laughing) What happened with your Auntie Nora?
She was, uhm- she was into wearing kaftans...
Yeah, I- I- I used to sit on the floor at home, in front of the telly.
She was on the chair behind--
She did a bit of a- sort of, a Sharon Stone scene--
It was like a ripped tennis ball.
Ice-T - That's How I'm Living Begins To Play
Right, we're off air. We're off air. Either that or put us in for the Sony's.
Bit of old school hip hop.
Go get me a cup of coffee or sommat.
Well, before we do that, can I just qualify something? I'm a little bit concerned about your--
Your toilet discussion. What- what exactly is your point again? I'm just a bit bemused.
Yeah, but- you see... it's- it's a tricky one. All I'm saying is, right, there I was at the pub quiz, I go to the toilet... not thinking about anything--
I try to go, right, there's a little gay fella next to me.
(Giggling) I love this little gay fella.
Now... the weird thing is there's nothing stopping him having a little- little glance, right? Because he's allowed in- in the fella's toilet.
Now I'm not allowed to go into the women's toilet... and have a little- have a little look 'round.
So all I'm saying is: should they have another- another toilet area?
And... so this would be gay men and lesbians?
I mean, I can only assume- I mean, to point- a- a- ask you a question, right. If you're intimidated, that's- I mean, that- that- that's a shame but you know most gay men aren't looking at your knob?
I can only say that 99.9 percent of gay men who use a urinal standing next to, what they assume is a heterosexual man, aren't looking at his knob.
Well, what are they doing, then?
No, but the thing is, you- you--
I can't t- I can't talk politics with Karl.
You're sayin'- you're sayin', like, you know, about "would you have one toilet for lesbian women and gay fellas?", right.
Well, what does that mean? Would it be mixed or would it just be--
Would it have a- would it have a man on one - that's for heterosexual men, a little picture of a woman on the other and... then what? What would (Laughing Slightly) the little icon be?
Two- a man and a woman.
Well, y- you couldn't mix 'em because then, what would happen is, you'd get people who- who are goin', "Ah, I'll play- I'll play up to this a bit--"
And yeah, n- you know, sort of, grow a mustache and shave their head...
And pretend to be a lesbian?
(Laughing) Right... Yeah... So- so, I see- so people are pretending to be gay so they can go in and look at the lesbians.
Right. So, that would mean that we need four cubicles now, would we?
Yeah, no, this is fine - four cubicles is fine--
(Laughing Slightly) So- so, every pub now--
How many toilets do we need at the moment?
(Laughing Slightly) Every pub has now got four toilets.
(Comical Tone) Bisexuals! How many toilets do we need nowww?
No, because they're interested in everything, aren't they?
Because the little bisexual fella will be looking at your... knob.
What you do - you just have a door, you open it and there's one urinal there. So you can't get a queue... They have to- they have to, sort of, wait--
I just thougth o- well, why can't there just be a thing between the urinals? So anyone- no one can look at anyone else's knob... full stop.

Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Just to go back to Ricky's point... What stops- even if we've got the toilet for gay men, what stops the gay men who want to have a look at your willy going in the regular toilet and pretending that they're straight?
They don't have a tattoo- there's no branding yet (Laughing Slightly) in the British Isles where they have to declare--
So, we're gonna have to expand this so we've all got to carry- carry identity cards--
What do you- do you- do you know it- you can see a gay, can ya, coming a mile off?
Nah, I'll just hold it in next time.
No, no, no, can you tell gay men? Do you know a gay man?
I'd say, uhhh... probably... If you did, like, a- if you lined some people up--
And said, "Point 'em out", I reckon I'd get--
But hold on, we're not talking about people dressed in leather with the ass cut out and a handlebar mustache--
We're talking about... you know, the everyday non-scene--
A- yeah, but I mean- supposing I put you in a room and there was ten naked men... right.
And, uh, could you- there's five gay men and five heterose- could you walk along that line looking at those gay--
(Laughing Slightly) No, you don't have to be naked. Why would you have to be naked?
Ricky Wheezes with Laughter and Stomps Around the Room
The Thrills - One Horse Town Begins to Play
How would you catch them out?
(Laughing) No, don't go into it! Don't go into it! Don't got into it. Play a record.

The Thrills, "One Horse Town" on XFM 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington. Now, Karl Pilkington is getting ready, it's the start of a new strand in the show, a new quiz, a new competition to replace "Rockbusters". Now that's quite a tall order but...

Right, like I said, right, if you've only just tuned in, what it is - I've took, and I'll be takin', a well known sayin' every week from the show -  something that crops up a lot - uhh, first one that sprang to mind... was...
"There's a little gay fella standin' next to me in the urinal"?
This week: "There's this hairy Chinese kid." Right?
That's cropped up quite a lot.
Right, so what I've done, I've got five songs...
And I've edited them together to make that sayin'.
You've got words- you've- from- from songs where any part of that sentence occurs--
Now, what do they need to do? Do they need to say what the song is? Just the five songs?
I mean I- I was gonna say song and artist but if you want, just the song.
So fi- there's five things there and if someone doesn't get all five, it's still worth emailing in because we might give it to the one who's got the most and then--

Can I suggest, uhh, we go for artists rather than song only because sometimes it's quite tricky to get a song title, sometimes it's a more- it's very odd or it's not quite what you think it is. So maybe artist is a- is an easier one.
It's y- are you happy with that, Karl? It's your competition.
I mean, Steve always does this, whenever I come up with an idea.
I'm just tryin' to make sure it's just the best it can be, Karl.
Yeah, no, you came up with a few gameshows and Steve was going, "No, it's no good." and Karl said to me, he said, "It's a wonder 'The Office' ever got on telly."
Yeah, but- well, we shall see how "Cheap as Chimps" plays out but, frankly, the fact that--

The fact that you said to me, "Steve, I've come up with the best gameshow ever, it's called 'Cheap as Chimps'" "What's the idea?" "I don't know, I just like the name... it has something to do with chimps." I thought, "Well, I'm not sure that's the best- the best gameshow ever."
And what was the other one you came up with and told me about?
I think a few people will be disagreeing with him, Karl. I think people will say that "Cheap as Chimps" could be the best gameshow ever.

You know, when I was at school, people like you, I really didn't like. You're a stirrer, Gervais. He flips, doesn't he, from one side to the next, Karl. One thing, we may argue, mate, but at least we're consistent. Ricky Gervais flippin' from one side to the other. One day he's on Karl's side--
Karl, when was the last time Steve wrestled you to the ground and got you in a leg clamp?
What? Is- is that supposed to be a good thing?
Yeah, I saw you struggling in the- (Laughs Slightly) in Karl's office, earlier.
He was punching my legs to release him. We were on the floor and I was squeezing him with my mighty legs, wasn't I Karl?
It was like- I imagine that's what a crab feels like when an octopus has got it.
We were playing that, weren't we?
So, I'll play this clip. Now, it's ten seconds long, we'll play it a couple of times cuz you'll need to take it in.
Ehh, so here it is, then... Eh, what are we sayin'? We're saying artists?
Artists. So, email in [emailprotected] Name the fa- five artists it has taken to make up the saying "There's this hairy Chinese kid".
Give that email address again. Give that email address again.
I think you better play it once more.

I should just remind you now - that the prizes include a, uh, "Red Dwarf" DVD, "Marion and Geoff", the first series of that on VHS, uh, a "Live Forever" Britpop CD and also "The Very Best of Led Zep- Led Zeppelin". Let's play one of those, actually, while we're here.

One of the prizes on Karl's competition this week is "The Very Best of Led Zeppelin". That's obviously "Rock and Roll". Uh, we've also got a "Live Forever" Britpop CD, "Marion and Geoff" and "Red Dwarf". And, uh, should we play it again so people have got another chance?
(Laughing Slightly) It's tricky. It's not very easy. Once more.

I, uh, at the quiz also discovered, of course, and, uhm- I don't know, I'm just intrigued to know, Karl- I'm just intrigued to know, uhmm.. It was your girlfriend's birthday wasn't it? Earlier in the week?
And, uhm, obviously it was a triumph, the stuff you got her for Christmas. Uhh--
The box- the box of condoms.
Box set- box set of condoms.
Not just- not just the singles--
So what'd you go for this time?
No, no, no, no, no, no, no--
No "yeah but", it's her birthday. How long have you been together?
Okay so... oooh, God it must cost you so much on her birthday!
No, but it starts gettin' tricky, dunnit, cuz I spoiled her a lot.
"Here's a packet of rubber bands. Enjoy them."
Well, she- it's what she wanted.
And you're makin' out as if--
Come on, what did you get her?
Got her a- a new pair of gloves.
What, a nice- nice leather ones from Salfridge's or Harrods or sommat?
Uh, they were good ones, the sort she likes. So... They weren't--
Oh, they we- they weren't the little woollen ones that she had?
I thought that was a joke when she said, "He got me these", cuz I laughed.
No, that's- but I know that's- the- the ones she did have, the--

When she said it was her birthday, right- it was her birthday Monday, and me and Steve w- "Oh, what did you get her?", and she went, "He got me these", cuz she had those little woollen gloves on, I laughed... cuz I thought she was joking, Karl.
I've told ya before about buyin' presents, it's- it's--
Do those gloves have your name sewn in them?
And a piece of string... that ran over the back of your duffle coat?
You know I've never been into gettin' presents and that. I had the problem at that Christmas one time with the Victoria Plum--
We'd hate to bring that back.
Cuz we've talked about that before- cuz it's kind of to do with your dad, is it? He's a very bad gift buyer, was that the problem?

Well, yeah, me dad's- I mean, me dad just wouldn't bother. It- it was me mam who, sort of, made an effort and she, sort of, worked out half of what I wanted, then she left it to me dad to get someone- see if he could get one cheap or whatever.
I- I love the fact that usually people talk about, like, drinking heavily--
Or, uhm, uh, violent abuse, right?
But, his- what he's been left with and scarred with for- for parents is bad gift buying.
In the greater scheme of things in the world--
That's not a bad thing to have, is it?
Right, there was this- there was this- this is what it's like about gettin' presents and stuff, right...
With me- with me mam and dad.
Me mate Colin, right, he had, uh--
Right? He had a, uh, little, uh, Sinclair Spectrum, right?
Which was, like, the- the thing to have at that time, right?
Used to always go around to his house. The deal was--
Not the one where you had to play through the window because you weren't allowed in--
No, no, no, that's another lad, right.
This is- this is a different lad and the deal was: he came to our house and me mam gave him a pie...
And then I'd go 'round to his and I'd stay there for a few hours playing, you know, "Hungry Horace" and stuff like that on it.

Right? Now, me mam and dad knew that I really wanted one of these... computers, right. So I waited about a year... Came 'round to Christmas Day, I thought, "I reckon, uh, I might have one."... Turned out, they bought me the wrong one... they bought me a ZX81 instead of a Spectrum--

And Christmas Day, I'm there trying to load the games up, it's not working, I'm thinking, "What's wrong?!", right. And the thing with me when I was a kid, I used to get quite, sort of, agitated quite easy--
This is the- this is the moment.

Right? I found out, that you needed a RAM pack to make it work... right... Lookin' in the thing and it's saying, "And make sure you put your RAM pack in the back". And I was like, "Awww... where's the RAM pack?" And me dad's goin', "I don't know, I've got you the main bit. That's- that's it."... So, I was that wound up, I just was sick, right--
Just sick. I w- I didn't feel sick or anything, I just was like, "Oh, God!", went to the sink, just- just sick.
Cuz I was that on edge about it.
I said, "Come on, we've gotta get one", and me dad's like, "Tandy's shut. We're not gonna- we're not gonna get anything today."
Ruined again, Christmas Day. That was after the year when me train set got blown up by our kid. The following year - no RAM pack. And now you ask me why I don't get good presents.
(Laughing) He's scarred. You just- just threw up.
I'm gonna die. Honestly, I'm gonna die. (Laughing) Just being sick.
Why wasn't- did you get to the bottom of it? Why wasn't there a RAM pack?
You have to buy them seperate.
"What do you mean I can't play 'Frogger'?! (Vomit Sound)"
So, uhm, wasn't there another incident when you threw up? Spontaneously threw up.
I- I do get it- it's not so much now cuz I've- I've relaxed a bit but as a kid I used to be quite on edge all the time with certain things.
Do you think that's what happened with your cat bein' sick?
That it didn't get the food it wanted and it just threw up. Do you remember that?
Yeah, but again, you see, the cat thing... I mean, it's mad, I was thinking about it the other day, right-  I used to think I had quite a normal upbringing.
Right. And someone was talkin' about the cat--
Your mother once told you not to go to school because it was windy, Karl!
It was not a normal upbringing.
The cat was bein' sick so she shaved it, so it was easier to clean.
Right, well me mam and dad went on holiday, right--
And I stayed at the Ross', down the road...
Only a kid - must of been about 5 or something, right?
And, uhh, I was always runnin' around in the house, I had a lot of energy as a kid.
What the Ross' did - they had this cat that was dead violent, the most violent, sort of, angry cat I have ever witnessed--
It was- honestly Steve... if it was bigger, it would have been cuz it was just always havin' a go at ya.

If you went to pat it on the head, it went to bite ya and stuff and what they used to do with it to stop me runnin' around- I'd, sort of, be runnin' around and I'd get a bit tired, and they'd say, "Have a lie down on the settee." So, I'd- I'd lie down on the settee and I'd nod off and what they used to do- I'd wake up and they'd have put the cat on me belly.
Right. So, I'd be scared to move cuz it's like, "It's gonna get me."
But it would keep you... there.
Right, it kept me there and it used to, sort of, slobber on me and they'd, sort of, go out or whatever and I'd be lying there... That's not normal, is it?
Karl, sorry, were you created by the Brothers Grimm for one of their fairy tales? What kind of life is that?!
A- a cat paperweight to keep Karl in place.

"He keeps blowing around, it's windy." "We'll have to weight him down!" "Be caref-" Your mum probably told 'em, "It's a windy you gotta keep something heavy on him, otherwise he just gets blown into the road." God!

They want me to do, uhh, like, a column, 500 words about--
Anything I want on monkeys. Anything.
Don't know, I've... you know, think about it and--
Well, give him a typewriter, he'll come up with (Laughing Slightly) the complete works of Shakespeare eventually.
You could write about that. Why don't you write about that? You don't- the fact that you don't believe it... You don't believe that an infinite number of monkeys--
Could type the works of Shakespeare.
Because you reckon that most of 'em hadn't read Shakespeare so they wouldn't know the- some of the spellings.

The, uh- there's been a few things but one that springs to mind... is, uh... they found a load of monkeys somewhere. All right?
I mean imagine this- if this was the news.
Uhhhhhh... I don't- it doesn't matter, that bit, right...
That are, uh, havin' a good chat.
(Laughing Slightly) They're having a good chat. All right.
They found monkeys that can talk...

Just, you know, things that monkeys are worryin' about.
Just... you know, "Where'd you get that from?" Uhhh--
"You're goin' out with her again, are ya?"
Sorry, you can't just leave that!
No, no, no, I'm just intrigued- I'm just intrigued to know what else. Is there any--
No, I mean, that- that was--
Were they discussing the "humanzee"? "Did you see that program on Channel 5?"
"Did you see how human he was?"
But, I mean, what- what do you mean? They taught them- they taught- they taught themselves this language?
Where? Where is this? In the wild, is this, is it?
It's in some jungle somewhere. They found these monkeys- they heard some, you know- some explorer was over there cutting through the- the woods and that--

Once again- but what I'm think- well, I mean, that did happen--
Uhhhm, and to, sort of, add to that feature...

So how many bananas do they eat a day? One chimp, per day, how many bananas?

How many bananas does it eat a day?
Uhm, how many bananas do you eat a day?
Well, I'll- I'll try and have two if I've got time--
How many- how many do you reckon?
I- I think, uhh, a little monkey, tiny little monkey, per day, (Laughs Slightly) uhh, over the course of a day, I reckon he probably eats fifteen bananas.

It's "How many bananas does it eat?" Come on, Rick!

How many bananas does it eat? Come on!
Yeah, cuz it only gets given one.

And- and, uhm- and why does it only eat one banana, cuz it only get's given one banana?
I think that's all it wants.
So you don't even know! You didn't even bother to ask--
No, it wouldn't- it wouldn't just get given one banana and nothing else, it would get given a banana and lots of other stuff like apples, oranges, carrots- it would get given a balanced diet.

Because he's just like- he loves everything Karl loves and he was telling Karl stuff and Karl's face was lighting up.

Karl went, "Exactly!" and the- and he said, "Have you heard of the one- the three-legged juggler?" and the bloke went, "No, what's that?", he went, "That annoys me as well." Because he thinks they shouldn't of done jugglin', they should have done football.

But the other day I was lookin' in, I don't know, "Bizarre Magazine" or something, right. And there was this fella who, uhh- he had no arms... Uhh, so you saw a picture of him. His job was fixin' watches - did it with his feet.
Well, it's just- why pick the most- hardest job to do when you haven't got any hands.

Ohhhh! "Crush grapes"! Imagine him bein' told that at the--

Brilliant. Brilliant. I would love you to be a career advisory i- in some, sort of... clinic. It'd be brilliant.

An incredible talent, an incredible skill, he's utilizing that brilliantly, that's annoying to you. You are angered by it.
